content:
Prince Klemens von Metternich played a key role in the development of the German Confederation as the chief architect of the system of governance that emerged from the Congress of Vienna in 1815. He advocated for a loose confederation of German-speaking states under Austrian leadership, with a weak central government that provided a framework for cooperation and coordination among the member states.

Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, on the other hand, was a leading intellectual and writer who was a proponent of the idea of a unified German nation-state. His literary works, such as "Faust" and "Wilhelm Meister," promoted a sense of national identity and unity among the German people. While he was not directly involved in the formation of the German Confederation, his ideas had a significant impact on the cultural and intellectual climate of the time and contributed to the eventual unification of Germany in 1871.
